Award.AwardTitle: US-Chile Planning Visit: Interdisciplinary Study of Water Management in an Arid Basin
Award.AbstractNarration:
This U.S - Chile Planning Visit proposal will support five senior researchers and three graduate students from the U.S., under the direction of Dr. Terry Jordan of Cornell University, on a planning visit to Chile. The project brings together an interdisciplinary team of geoscientists, economists, and engineers from Chile and the U.S. The U.S. investigators will collaborate intensively with colleagues from Pontificia Universidad Católica, Universidad del Desarollo, and Universidad Católica del Norte in Chile. Researchers will develop a plan to investigate water sustainability in a changing natural environment and under increased pressure from human withdrawals. The team will visit the Calamana Basin in Northern Chile to develop concepts, quantify uncertainties and impacts, and model water management choices. This research would also provide a systems analysis that would be applicable for other semi-arid to arid regions such as southwest U.S.

The visit will involve five senior U.S. researchers, two who are female, and three graduate students. It has the potential to generate long-term interdisciplinary collaborations in sustainability science between U.S. and Chilean researchers and further our understanding of water management choices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the world, water demand is increasing for industrial, agricultural, and household use. Yet societies are also concerned with the preservation of water-related environments. Accordingly, the design of sustainable water management systems involves tradeoffs between sustainability objectives for environmental features and for the economic welfare of the human population. Examining the tradeoffs involved in water management and exploring conditions when these two sustainability notions overlap or diverge is the key objective of this research. The short-term goals of this NSF Office of International Science and Engineering-sponsored grant were to develop an interdisciplinary team of adequate breadth and knowledge to attack this complex problem, to enable them to communicate effectively across disciplinary boundaries, and to launch basic research projects focused on sustainable water management that will persist far beyond this initial grant.

In this project, a team of economists and geoscientists together explored a water system, its management, and the overlaps and conflicts involved in meeting the two sustainability objectives. We focused on a system in northern Chile, the Loa river basin, which exemplifies the challenges to water supply systems in the western US, China, India, and many other regions. Yet the Loa system is a simpler case in which to identify tradeoffs because there is a small number of individual participants, a very clear link to a nation’s economic well-being, and a simple and clear legal code for water. During an 11-day-long group trip to Chile, we met with stakeholders (government agency officers, mining industry managers, municipal water supply managers, agriculturalists, political decision makers, indigenous community members, etc.) and academic collaborators. Jointly we identified key natural and human system components to which this intersection of sustainability goals is most sensitive and we examined the tradeoffs involved when meeting one objective compromises the other.

The collaborating team grew through the series of interactions during the study visit to involve geologists, hydrologists, engineers, and economists from Chile, and fused to function as an interdisciplinary team. Follow-up research has been of three types. First, an economist and a hydrogeologist among the team members have developed a simple numerical model to explore the economic tradeoffs in a system in which human extraction of water is regulated for both streamflow criteria and groundwater-fed wetland criteria, for which they are using an historical case in the Loa basin as a case study.  This interdisciplinary model is the first step on a path toward a more expansive system-wide model. Three economists from the team, US and Chilean, are completing an analysis of the full costs of use of desalinated water for mining in the Loa region.  Four geoscientists developed and are now calibrating a static model of the groundwater and surface water throughout the Loa drainage basin, which can later be used to test alternative scenarios for management. Partnerships between the US investigators and Chilean investigators and stakeholders that grew as a result of this NSF Office of International Science and Engineering-sponsored project are facilitating all of these projects.
